channel.title: The Backfire Effect
channel.description:
Someone linked me to a rather interesting article, found here: http://youarenotsosmart.com/2011/06/10/the-backfire-effect/
It is essentially an overview of human rationalisation. Most important though is that it highlights the total inability to sway a person who has truly made their mind up on a matter. Will Frell and Radeon ever convince the other to change sides? No.
Anyway, discuss!

item.title: The Backfire Effect
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Frell:

Guns don’t alter your judgement and perspective of reality

what relevance does that have?

Frell:

weed costs more to regulate than they would get in return from taxes

I call bullshit on that, how much does your country spend on fixing problems caused by alcohol? drunk driving, health issues, vandalism etc are some very real, very costly things that have to be paid for

Frell:

alcohol has been prohibited once already(here atleast)

and it was a huge succ- failure because it led to organized crime and corruption because those who broke the law made huge profits doing so, and by comparison todays drug dealers and gangs are making huge amounts of money selling drugs and simply do not want drugs legalized because they make money charging what they want for drugs

here’s a thought, if drugs were legal and could be bought from shops then who would buy their drugs from the violent criminals?

Frell:

almost every other drug can easily kill you, and if not can cause some pretty hefty damage. Its just not something you let float around.

again what relevance does that have, even if it were true? most drugs are relatively safe if used properly in the first place but because most people may lack a proper education about drugs they can easily be misused

I’ll give you a real world example, we all know drink driving is ridiculously dangerous and can get you and other innocent people killed, and you don’t even need to drink to know this

I have yet to see a convincing argument to keep drugs illegal and the users criminals that can’t be applied to alcohol, it’s a rather arbitary line you have to admit

item.title: The Backfire Effect
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Lothy:

If a definitive study was released tomorrow that revealed that marijuana did indeed cause schizophrenia in all users after a period of time, irrespective of predisposition and medical history, I think many of the people here would still continue to use it, and still sought to have it legalised.

Yep, I’d be one of those people.

But that has very little to do with immutable beliefs. We know that drugs are dangerous now, and I still want them legalised. You don’t legalise them because they’re safe. We know that weapons can be used to kill people, yet people still seek their legalisation.

This is kind of off-topic, but I do always love when people prove to me that they don’t understand why people fight for drug legalisation by assuming everyone must just have their head in their clouds and be ignoring the effects.

(We also KNOW that alcohol causes liver damage and addiction)

item.title: The Backfire Effect
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:7, topic:399493”][quote author=goatee link=topic=496623.msg3631217#msg3631217 date=1308243527]
Same, if I’m given some information that is factual and against my current views, I’d be willing to be swayed.
[/quote]
Yea, me too. I’ve changed my views on some things like that.[/quote]
You have plenty of immutable views, at least as far as discussion on this forum reveals.
Examples include American cars, firearms, homosexuality, and the existence of a God.

I shouldn’t make an absolute statement about it, but I’ve got a feeling that quite a few people here hold unshakable beliefs with regards to drugs.
If a definitive study was released tomorrow that revealed that marijuana did indeed cause schizophrenia in all users after a period of time, irrespective of predisposition and medical history, I think many of the people here would still continue to use it, and still sought to have it legalised.

With that said, I actually can’t think of anything that I believe in to the extent that I would continue to believe it when faced with scientific evidence.
It seems to be one of those things that you take for granted, and it takes someone else to point it out.
